required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Impact of Training With Whole Body-EMS
clinical_study.official_title: The Impact of Training With Whole Body-EMS

brief_summary.textblock: Researchers are trying to find out what impact training with whole body-EMS (Electronic muscle stimulation) has on various health outcomes.

detailed_description.textblock: All subjects in both groups who enroll into this study will undergo an assessment of peripheral endothelial function with reactive hyperemia-peripheral arterial tonometry (RH-PAT) testing using EndoPAT; an assessment of vital signs including heart rate, blood pressure, weight, height and body mass index; laboratory blood work; cardiorespiratory testing using treadmill testing to determine VO2 max and maximal tolerated heart rate; maximal strength and maximal power testing on chest press and leg press testing; and percent body fat and fat distribution testing at baseline, and at 16-weeks follow-up (immediately after completing a 16-week training program using whole body-EMS). Baseline cardiovascular risk factors will be assessed by subject questionnaire and verified by chart review. In addition, subjects will complete an angina/chest pain symptom questionnaire (Rose Questionnaire), quality of life questionnaire (LASA Questionnaire), depression questionnaire (Patient Health Questionaire-9) and perceived stress questionnaire (Perceived Stress Scale) to assess for psychosocial wellness at each point in the study.

primary_outcome.description: To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week, on peripheral endothelial function as measured using EndoPAT.

secondary_outcome.description: To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week, on:i) Body mass index, waist circumference, percentage body fat and distribution, and blood pressure

secondary_outcome.measure: Impact of EMS on Serum Lipid Profile
secondary_outcome.description: To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week to Serum lipid profile

To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week, on:iii) VO2 maximum (Cardiopulmonary exercise testing parameters

secondary_outcome.measure: Impact of EMS on Maximum Strength & Power in Chest Press and Leg Press
secondary_outcome.description: To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week, on:iv) Maximum strength and maximum power in chest press and leg press
To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week, on:v) Symptoms of angina as measured by the Rose Questionnaire

secondary_outcome.measure: Impact of EMS to Longitudinal Amsterdam Aging Study Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.description: To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week, on:vi) Quality of life as measured by the Longitudinal Amsterdam Aging Study Questionnaire, with values of 0-10 (0 being as bad as it can be and 10 being as good as it can be)
To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week, on:vii) Temporal changes in blood levels of creatinine kinase

secondary_outcome.measure: Impact of EMS to Perceived Stress Scale
secondary_outcome.description: To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week, on symptoms of stress as measured on the Perceived Stress Scale with values of 0 to 4, with 0 being never stressed and 4 being very often stressed.

secondary_outcome.measure: Impact of EMS to Patient Health Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.description: To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week on Quality of life as measured by the Patient Health Questionnaire with a score of 0-27; 0 being no depression and 27 being severe depression.

secondary_outcome.measure: Impact of EMS on Blood Glucose
secondary_outcome.description: To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week on Blood Glucose
To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week on HbA1c

secondary_outcome.measure: Impact of EMS on High-Sensitivity CRP
secondary_outcome.description: To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week on high-sensitivity CRP

secondary_outcome.measure: Impact of EMS on Uric Acid
secondary_outcome.description: To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week on uric acid.
To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week on fibrinogen
To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week on homocysteine.
To assess the impact of training with whole body-EMS for a 16-week period of time, involving 1.0 x 20 minute training sessions per week on lipoprotein.

arm_group.description: EMS device will be turned on during exercise for this group.
EMS device will be turned off during exercise for this group.

intervention.description: The EMS Device will turned on during exercise as opposed to it being turned off for control group.
The EMS Device will turned off during exercise as opposed to it being turned off for control group.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy individuals
- Employees at the Mayo Clinic, Rochester MN
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects under the age of 18
- Pregnant women
- Subjects with a history of liver or kidney disease, acute illness, taking medications (such as glucocorticoids)
- Subjects who have conditions (such as chronic inflammatory muscular diseases or Cushing's syndrome) that affect muscle mass
- Individuals with pacemakers and implantable cardiac defibrillators
- Individuals who conduct any other type of resistance training (> 45 minutes/week)
- Individuals who have regular "high" alcohol consumption (> 80g/day on 5 days a week)
- Subjects unable to consent to or participate in the 16-week EMS intervention or be available for follow up
